conclusion: The problem involves calculating the work done by the frictional force on an object as it moves along a conveyor belt from point M to point N.
The conveyor belt moves clockwise at a speed of 6 m/s. The distance between the two drive wheels M and N is 10 m. An object is placed on the conveyor belt directly above wheel M.
The object has a mass of 3 kg, the coefficient of kinetic friction between the object and the conveyor belt is 0.3, and the acceleration due to gravity is 10 m/s².

premise: The object starts at point M with an initial velocity of 0 and moves to point N on the conveyor belt.
conclusion: The object starts from rest at point M and moves to point N.

premise: The coefficient of kinetic friction is 0.3, the mass of the object is 3 kg, and g = 10 m/s².
conclusion: The frictional force acting on the object is F = μmg = 0.3 × 3 × 10 = 9 N.

premise: The frictional force acting on the object is F = 9 N, and the mass of the object is 3 kg.
conclusion: The acceleration of the object due to friction is a = F/m = 9/3 = 3 m/s².

premise: The velocity of the conveyor belt is 6 m/s, and the acceleration of the object is 3 m/s².
conclusion: The time taken for the object to match the conveyor belt's speed is t = v/a = 6/3 = 2 s.

premise: The acceleration of the object is 3 m/s², and the time of sliding is t = 2 s.
conclusion: The displacement of the object during sliding is L = 0.5 × a × t² = 0.5 × 3 × 2² = 6 m.

premise: The displacement of the object during sliding is 6 m, which is less than the total distance of 10 m.
conclusion: The object stops sliding after 6 m, and the frictional force stops acting.

premise: The frictional force acting on the object is F = 9 N, and the displacement during sliding is L = 6 m.
conclusion: The work done by the frictional force is W = F × L = 9 × 6 = 54 J.
